user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_MutSemGive_Impl:
```c
int32 OS_MutSemGive_Impl(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    int                              status;
    OS_impl_mutex_internal_record_t *impl;

    impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_mutex_table, *token);

    /*
     ** Unlock the mutex
     */
    status = pthread_mutex_unlock(&(impl->id));
    if (status != 0)
    {
        return OS_SEM_FAILURE;
    }

    return OS_SUCCESS;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_MutSemGive_Impl:
#define OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(tbl, tok) (&tbl[OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(&(tok))])
...
OS_impl_mutex_internal_record_t OS_impl_mutex_table[OS_MAX_MUTEXES]
...
static inline osal_index_t OS_ObjectIndexFromToken(const OS_object_token_t *token)
{
    return token->obj_idx;
}
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
typedef struct
{
    pthread_mutex_t id;
} OS_impl_mutex_internal_record_t
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No code fragment modifies the function parameter itself. Reasoning:

- The function parameter is declared as const OS_object_token_t *token; the code never assigns to token (no statements like token = ...), so the parameter variable is not modified.
- The macro invocation impl = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_impl_mutex_table, *token) expands to use &(*token) (because the macro uses &(tok)); &(*token) is equivalent to token, so this only reads the pointer and its pointee to compute an index — it does not modify the parameter.
- OS_ObjectIndexFromToken takes a const OS_object_token_t * and returns token->obj_idx, which only reads the object; it does not alter the pointer or the pointed-to object.
- The assignment to impl stores a pointer into a local variable; this does not change the parameter.
- The call to pthread_mutex_unlock(&(impl->id)) operates on the mutex object (impl->id), not on the function parameter. Modification of the object referred to by a pointer parameter is permitted by the rule; the prohibition is only on modifying the parameter (the pointer) itself.

Therefore there are no fragments in the provided code that violate MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 and no additional fragments require investigation under this rule.
